title: How to Tackle Difficult Reading Material

steps.headline: Read the title and think about what it means and which resources might help you (for example Italian dictionary or atlas).
Underline words you don't know.
steps.description: It is essential to be honest with yourself (after all no one is looking!). If you cannot use a word in a sentence you don't understand what it means. Imagine yourself in a real-world situation, using the word to describe something to a stranger.

steps.headline: Write very short summaries for chunks of the text that seem appropriate.
steps.description: The frequency of these summaries will depend on the material itself and your ability to read it. If it's a rather daunting book, then write a summary for every paragraph or half a paragraph.

steps.headline: Visualize the ideas with simple flow diagrams.
steps.description: For example, you may create a flow diagram that indicates the plot, or the relationships between characters.

steps.headline: Explain the new idea to a person and try to get the person excited about it.
steps.description: (If you have no one, imagine telling it to a number of persons like A. the bus driver B. a drunk girl C. Barack Obama D. a 5 year old child).

steps.headline: Use any background information you may have on the topic.
steps.description: Connection will help you become more knowledgeable about certain topics, leaving you able to learn even more.

steps.headline: Explain the thought-train to yourself in front of a mirror.
Make sure to notice uncertainties and read these passages again.
Make sure to re-read the whole text when you have proceeded through all the chunks: Finally understanding it and seeing the whole picture will be an incredible reward.
